title: Paper: Midwifery FQE July 2025
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - July 2025

questions.question: The term fetus is used in pregnancy for;
questions.explanation: In human embryology, the prenatal period is divided into three stages: Pre-embryonic (0-2 weeks), Embryonic (2-8 weeks), and Fetal stage (from 9 weeks until birth). The fetal stage is characterized by rapid growth and maturation of tissues.
questions.hint: Think about the stage that comes after the embryonic period.

questions.question: This is the hormone that is primarily responsible for stimulating spermatogenesis in the testes
questions.explanation: FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) acts directly on the Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules to initiate and maintain spermatogenesis. LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, which is essential but FSH is the primary stimulator.
questions.hint: This hormone has 'follicle' in its name, even in males.

questions.question: Which uterine ligament originates from the anterior aspect of the cervix and is responsible for pulling the cervix forward?
questions.explanation: Pubocervical ligaments extend from the anterior aspect of the cervix to the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis, maintaining the cervix in its anterior position. Uterosacral ligaments pull the cervix backwards.
questions.hint: The name of the ligament suggests it connects the pubis to the cervix.

questions.question: The true conjugate diameter of the pelvis is a critical measurement in midwifery. This diameter is measured from;

options.text: The sacral promontory to the upper edge of the pubic symphysis
The sacral promontory to the lower edge of the pubic symphysis
One ischial spine to the other ischial spine
The pubic symphysis to the coccyx

questions.explanation: The True Conjugate (Anatomical Conjugate) is measured from the center of the sacral promontory to the upper border of the pubic symphysis (approx 11 cm). The measurement to the lower edge is the Diagonal Conjugate.
questions.hint: Think 'True' equals 'Top' of the symphysis.

questions.question: In the fetal circulation, oxygenated blood enters the fetal circulation from the umbilical vein via;
questions.explanation: Oxygenated blood travels from the placenta via the umbilical vein. A significant portion bypasses the liver through the Ductus Venosus to enter the inferior vena cava directly.
questions.hint: This structure connects a vein to a vein (venous duct).

questions.question: A nurse is teaching a group of nursing students about physiology of pregnancy. The nurse tells the students that fetal weight gain is greatly increased in the;
questions.explanation: The most significant increase in fetal weight occurs during the third trimester, where the fetus gains subcutaneous fat and muscle mass. Earlier trimesters focus on organogenesis and length.
questions.hint: Weight gain is the final preparation for birth.

questions.question: Mrs. Q who is 35 weeks pregnant complains to the nurse during prenatal visit that her breathing has become difficult. The nurse should respond by telling the client that;

options.text: Her lower rib cage is more restricted by the fetus hence the breathing difficulty
Her diaphragm has been displaced upward hence the breathing difficulty
There is an increase in the size of her lungs hence the breathing difficulty
There is an increase in the size of her heart hence the breathing difficulty

questions.explanation: As the uterus enlarges, it pushes upward on the diaphragm, displacing it by about 4 cm. This causes physiological dyspnea in late pregnancy before lightening occurs.
questions.hint: Think about what physical structure separates the abdomen from the chest.

questions.question: How does a nurse identify true labour as opposed to false labour when admitting a patient in labour ward?

options.text: Cervical dilatation and effacement is progressive
Contractions stop when the client walks around
Contractions progress only in a side lying position
Contractions occur immediately after the membranes rupture

questions.explanation: The definitive sign of true labor is progressive cervical change (effacement and dilatation). False labor contractions are irregular and do not cause cervical change.
questions.hint: Focus on the changes happening to the cervix.

questions.question: Arrange the cardinal movements of labor in the correct chronological sequence for a normal vaginal delivery:
questions.explanation: The classic sequence is: Descent (continuous), Flexion (chin to chest), Internal Rotation (to pass ischial spines), Extension (birth of head), External Rotation (restitution), and Expulsion (birth of shoulders/body).
questions.hint: The baby must first move down, tuck its chin, and rotate inside before extending the head out.

questions.question: As a nurse is monitoring a mother during the active phase of the first stage of labor, the expected rate of cervical dilation for a primigravida is:
questions.explanation: The WHO partograph defines the active phase alert line at 1 cm/hr. For a primigravida, a rate of 1-1.2 cm/hr is considered normal progress.
questions.hint: Active labor progress is typically measured as at least 1 cm every hour.

questions.question: A nurse in the prenatal clinic is assessing a woman at 34 weeks gestation with BP 166/100 mmHg, +3 proteinuria, severe headache, and blurred vision. What is the appropriate nursing action?

options.text: Arrange immediate transportation to the hospital
Obtain a prescription for an antihypertensive

questions.explanation: This client exhibits signs of Severe Pre-eclampsia (BP >160/110, severe proteinuria, cerebral symptoms). This is an obstetric emergency requiring immediate hospital admission for stabilization and potential delivery.
questions.hint: This is a life-threatening emergency, not a routine clinic case.

questions.question: The midwife notes a soft and boggy uterus one hour after birth. What is the initial nursing intervention?

options.text: Push on the uterus to express clots
Massage the fundus until firm, administer oxytocin

questions.explanation: A 'boggy' uterus indicates uterine atony. The first-line action is fundal massage to mechanically stimulate contraction, followed by oxytocics. Pushing on a boggy uterus can cause inversion.
questions.hint: Mechanical stimulation is the first step to fix a relaxed muscle.

questions.question: What is the expected timeline for uterine involution during puerperium?
questions.explanation: Involution of the uterus takes approximately 6 weeks to return to its non-pregnant size and location through contraction, retraction, and autolysis.
questions.hint: It matches the standard duration of the postnatal period.

questions.question: Which factor is associated with an increased risk of developing postpartum depression?
questions.explanation: Major risk factors for PPD include unplanned/unwanted pregnancy, history of depression, and lack of social support. High SES is protective.
questions.hint: Think about psychosocial stressors.

questions.question: How does exclusive breastfeeding physiologically impact the mother during puerperium?
questions.explanation: Suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin, which causes the milk ejection reflex and simultaneous uterine contractions ('afterpains'), aiding involution.
questions.hint: The hormone that releases milk also contracts the uterus.

questions.question: A mother asks how to care for her newbornâ€™s umbilical cord stump. The midwife should advise her to:

options.text: Provide sponge baths until the cord falls off

questions.explanation: The cord stump should be kept clean and dry to prevent infection. Tub baths can keep it wet, so sponge baths are recommended until separation. Drainage is a sign of infection.
questions.hint: The goal is to keep the cord dry.

questions.question: What is a primary physiological benefit of immediate skin-to-skin contact for the newborn?

options.text: Enhanced immune response via maternal flora

questions.explanation: Skin-to-skin contact promotes colonization with maternal flora (immune benefit), stabilizes temperature (prevents hypothermia), and encourages early breastfeeding.
questions.hint: It helps the baby's microbiome.

questions.question: A 3-day-old newborn has yellow discoloration of the sclera and soles. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation: Jaundice appearing on day 3 is typically Physiological Jaundice, caused by immature liver function and RBC breakdown. Pathological jaundice (sepsis, incompatibility) usually appears within the first 24 hours.
questions.hint: Consider the timing (Day 3) which is typical for 'normal' newborn jaundice.

questions.question: Which reflex is characterized by sudden extension and then flexion of arms in response to a loud noise?
questions.explanation: The Moro (Startle) reflex involves abduction/extension of arms followed by adduction/flexion ('embrace') in response to sudden stimulation.
questions.hint: Also known as the startle reflex.

questions.question: Which newborn is at highest risk for developing hypoglycemia?

options.text: Infant of mother with gestational hypertension

questions.explanation: Preterm and Small for Gestational Age (SGA) infants are at high risk for hypoglycemia due to limited glycogen stores.
questions.hint: Small babies have smaller energy reserves.

questions.question: A preterm infant (30 weeks) presents with grunting and a 'ground-glass' appearance on chest X-ray. This is diagnostic of:
questions.explanation: RDS (Hyaline Membrane Disease) is common in preterms due to surfactant deficiency. The classic X-ray finding is a reticulogranular 'ground-glass' pattern with air bronchograms.
questions.hint: This condition is related to surfactant deficiency.

questions.question: Which of the following include teratogenic causes of congenital malformations?
questions.explanation: Teratogens are environmental agents causing defects. Radiation (X-rays) and chemical substances (alcohol, drugs) are classic examples.
questions.hint: Think of external environmental factors that damage the fetus.

questions.question: A newborn has right-sided facial paralysis. Which clinical sign would you expect?

options.text: Right eye open, mouth drawn to the left
Right eye open, mouth drawn to the right
Left eye open, mouth drawn to the right
Left eye open, mouth drawn to the left

questions.explanation: In right-sided paralysis, the muscles on the right are weak. The right eye stays open (cannot close). The mouth is pulled to the UNAFFECTED (left) side by the healthy muscles.
questions.hint: The healthy side pulls the mouth towards it.

questions.question: A newborn presents with purulent conjunctivitis 2 days after birth. The likely causative organism is:
questions.explanation: Gonococcal ophthalmia typically presents early (2-5 days) with severe purulent discharge. Chlamydia presents later (5-14 days).
questions.hint: This organism causes rapid, severe, pus-filled eye infection.

questions.question: Epidural anesthesia is contra-indicated in women with which of the following conditions? (Select correct option)
questions.explanation: Epidurals cause vasodilation (worsening hypovolemia), risk spinal hematoma in coagulopathy, and risk meningitis if placed through local infection.
questions.hint: Think about bleeding risks and blood pressure drops.

questions.question: Which nonpharmacologic pain relief strategy involves reducing the woman's awareness of the external environment?
questions.explanation: Hypnosis involves a state of focused concentration where awareness of the external environment is reduced to alter pain perception.
questions.hint: It involves a trance-like state.

questions.question: Risks associated with teenage pregnancy during the antenatal period include which triad?
questions.explanation: Teenage mothers have higher physiological risks for Anemia, Pre-eclampsia (PIH), and STIs/HIV.
questions.hint: Think about medical conditions common in young, developing bodies.

questions.question: Hyperemesis gravidarum is associated with which group of conditions?
questions.explanation: Hyperemesis is linked to high HCG levels. Conditions with elevated HCG include Molar pregnancy and Multiple gestation.
questions.hint: Think of conditions with very high hormone levels.

questions.question: When is ART initiated in a pregnant woman who tests positive for HIV?

options.text: On the same day diagnosis is made

questions.explanation: Current 'Test and Treat' guidelines mandate immediate initiation of lifelong ART for all pregnant women upon diagnosis.
questions.hint: Immediate action prevents transmission.

questions.question: A baby born to a diabetic mother should be observed for which triad of complications?
questions.explanation: Infants of Diabetic Mothers risk Hypoglycemia (not hyper), Respiratory Distress Syndrome (insulin blocks surfactant), and Jaundice.
questions.hint: High insulin levels in the baby drop blood sugar after birth.

questions.question: Which institution ensures children are placed in suitable homes in their best interest?
questions.explanation: Adoption agencies are specifically mandated to vet homes and facilitate placement.
questions.hint: They specialize in finding families.

questions.question: What structures are involved in a third-degree perineal tear?
questions.explanation: 3rd degree involves the anal sphincter. 1st is skin, 2nd is muscle, 4th involves rectal mucosa.
questions.hint: It goes deeper than muscle but stops before the rectal lining.

questions.question: In a frank breech presentation, the legs are:

options.text: Flexed at hips, extended at knees

questions.explanation: Frank breech ('Pike' position) has hips flexed and knees extended, with feet near the head.
questions.hint: Feet are up by the ears.

questions.question: Which maneuver is used to deliver a breech with extended legs?
questions.explanation: Pinard's maneuver is used to flex the extended knee to deliver the foot.
questions.hint: Starts with 'P' for 'Pop the knee'.

questions.question: What is the presenting diameter in a face presentation?
questions.explanation: In a fully extended face presentation, the Sub-mento bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) presents, allowing vaginal delivery.
questions.hint: It measures from below the chin to the fontanelle.

questions.question: What characterizes a third-degree uterine inversion?
questions.explanation: Third-degree inversion is complete prolapse where the inverted fundus is visible outside the introitus.
questions.hint: It is visible externally.

questions.question: Which position is best for correcting uterine inversion?
questions.explanation: Trendelenburg (head down) uses gravity to help replace the uterus and relieves traction.
questions.hint: Use gravity to help the uterus go back 'up'.

questions.question: What is the outcome of labor with short internal rotation in an occipito-posterior position?
questions.explanation: Short rotation puts the occiput in the hollow of the sacrum (Direct OP), resulting in a 'Face to Pubis' delivery.
questions.hint: The baby comes out looking up.

questions.question: Monozygotic twins are characterized by:

options.text: Same sex, one ovum, one placenta (usually)

questions.explanation: Monozygotic twins come from one egg/sperm, so they are genetically identical and same sex.
questions.hint: Identical genes mean identical sex.

questions.question: A Rhesus negative mother needs RhIG (Anti-D) if:
questions.explanation: RhIG prevents sensitization to the Rh antigen. It is only needed if the baby has the antigen (Rh Positive).
questions.hint: The shot hides the 'Positive' cells from the mother.

questions.question: Which of the following are objectives of Focused Antenatal Care (FANC)? (Select 4)

options.text: Early detection and treatment of complications

questions.explanation: FANC objectives include: 1. Early detection/treatment, 2. Prevention (IPTp, TT), 3. Birth Preparedness, 4. Health Education.
questions.hint: Think of the medical and planning goals of ANC.

questions.question: Select the common breast complications that may occur during puerperium. (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Common puerperal complications are Engorgement (swelling), Cracked Nipples (trauma), and Mastitis (infection).
questions.hint: Think of issues related to breastfeeding initiation.

questions.question: What are the physiological effects of severe pain during labor? (Select 2)

options.text: Maternal hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis

questions.explanation: Pain causes hyperventilation (alkalosis) and stress hormone release (catecholamines), which constricts vessels and reduces blood flow to the fetus.
questions.hint: Pain causes stress responses.

questions.question: Match the anatomical relations of the uterus:
questions.explanation: The bladder is in front, rectum behind, vagina below, and intestines above the uterus.
questions.hint: Think about what organs are in front and behind the womb.

questions.question: Which of the following are passive movements in the mechanism of normal labor after descent? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: After descent, the head undergoes Flexion (chin tuck), Internal Rotation (to pass outlet), and Extension (birth).
questions.hint: Tuck, Turn, Look up.

questions.question: Identify the key components of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL). (Select 3)
questions.explanation: AMTSL consists of: 1. Oxytocin w/in 1 min, 2. CCT, 3. Uterine Massage.
questions.hint: Drug, Pull, Rub.

questions.question: Select the correct causes and signs of Oligohydramnios. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Sign: Smaller fundal height than dates

questions.explanation: Oligohydramnios (low fluid) is caused by renal failure (no urine) or leakage. Signs include small uterus and molding of uterus around fetus.
questions.hint: Low fluid means the baby is cramped and 'dry'.

questions.question: Identify the characteristics of a Small for Gestational Age (SGA) baby. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Large head in proportion to body

questions.explanation: SGA babies have a wasted appearance due to lack of fat/glycogen, appearing thin with a relatively large head and loose skin.
questions.hint: They look 'starved' or wasted.

questions.question: Regarding the management of a Small for Gestational Age (SGA) baby in the first 48 hours, which interventions are indicated? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Initiate early and frequent feeding to prevent hypoglycemia

questions.explanation: SGA babies are prone to Hypothermia (large surface area) and Hypoglycemia (low reserves). Management focuses on warmth, frequent feeding, glucose monitoring, and infection control.
questions.hint: Focus on warmth and sugar levels.
